 Leah is seeking a loan to purchase farm implements. Farming tools are very crucial to all farmers regardless of the nature of the agribusiness they are involved in. With your loan, Leah will acquire farm implements that will make her work in the field much easier and efficient. These benefits will translate to efficiency, improved quality and profits. Additional income as a result will help Leah to foot the high farming costs that keep rising by the day. When asked, "How will this loan benefit your family?", Leah replied "More income will help me buy more assets and be able to pay school fees for my school going children.”

loans.use: To buy farm implements

loans.name: Leonor Olivia

texts.es: Leonor: Es una señora amable de 60 años de edad, casada tiene 3 hijos mayores de edad. Desde hace 10 años habita en una vivienda de tambo de madera, con 7 personas. Solicita financiamiento para comprar materiales de construcción: madera, zinc, clavo y cubrir costos de mano de obra. Su sueño es tener una vivienda segura de concreto.
texts.en: Leonor is a kind, 60-year-old woman who is married and has three grown children. For 10 years she has been living in a wooden stilt house with 7 people. She is requesting a loan to buy building materials such as wood, zinc roofing sheets, and nails, and to cover labor costs. Her dream is to have a sturdy concrete house.

loans.use: to buy building materials such as wood, zinc roofing sheets, and nails, and to cover labor costs.

loans.name: Elisha

texts.en:
Elisha is a maize farmer from Nigeria. He is the father of 3 children.

A loan from Kiva helps Elisha to purchase fertilizer for his crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable him to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona,  he had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows him to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income. Elisha spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural inputs and store his harvest to sell it later at higher prices

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is a maize farmer from Nigeria. 

A loan from Kiva helps Thomas to purchase fertilizer for his crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable him to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, he had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows him to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and store his harvest to sell it later at higher prices

loans.name: Delu

texts.en:
Delu is a maize farmer from Nigeria. She is the mother of 3 children.

A loan from Kiva helps her to purchase fertilizer for her crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable her to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona,  she had to sell her maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, she can now store her maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows her to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income. 

When asked, Delu spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural inputs and store her harvest to sell it later at higher prices.

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel is a maize farmer from Nigeria. He is the father of 3 children. 

A loan from Kiva helps him to purchase fertilizer for his crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable him to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, he had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as clothing food (and school fees). With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support,he can now store his maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows Gabriel to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

loans.use: To pruchase agricultural inputs and store his harvest to sell it later on at higher prices

loans.name: Jay Maa Santoshi Shg (A) Group

texts.en:
Jay Maa Santoshi Self-Help Group (A) comprises nine members from Belaguntha village of Dhenkanal district, Odisha, India. All the nine members were from very humble families, and they started this group with the leadership of Sarojini. 

Initially they were able to deposit and save only a little amount because of the low income of their husbands. Later, their funds increased with the little profits, and they were able start their individual business, and a few gave it to their husbands to use in the family business. And slowly, slowly, with their little savings, they were able to make enough money to buy a small plot of land in the name of their group so that all the members could work together and make profits, rather than investing in individual businesses. They grew vegetables on their land and earned good profits, which they invested in irrigation (i.e., purchase of a water pump), digging of a well, and also purchasing pesticides, fertilizers, etc.

But, they wanted to grow a double crop, for which they needed more funds for purchase of land for paddy cultivation, pulses, oil seeds, etc. They applied for a loan from People’s Forum for the purchase of more land.

The ladies who were shy to step out of their homes are now an inspiration to many. They aim to be landladies of 4-5 acres of land and cultivate agricultural products with modern techniques.

The leader of this group, Sarojini, will use her portion to especially buy water pumps and seeds.

loans.use: to especially buy water pumps and seeds.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 33 years old and lives in the town of Maganjo in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has five children, with four of them currently in school. For the past seven years, Josephine has been working hard to manage her retail business, which sells soda, water, and beer. 

To help expand her business, Josephine has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more water, soda, and beer, and will help Josephine to generate greater profits and increase the family income. Josephine hopes that in the future she will be able to become a wholesaler. 

Josephine is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Josephine who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more water, soda, and beer

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is 45 years old, and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, with three of them currently in school. For the past two years, Fred has been working hard to manage his clothing shop, which sells dresses, bags, and t-shirts. 

To help expand his business, Fred has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more trousers, shirts, dresses, and bags, and will help Fred to generate greater profits and add stock to the shop. He hopes that in the future he will be able to expand the business. 

Fred is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Fred who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more trousers, shirts, dresses, and bags

loans.name: Erisa

texts.en:
Erisa is 40 years old and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has four children with two of them currently in school. For the past two years, Erisa has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells posho, rice, beans, salt, sodas, bananas, bread, and cooking oil. 

To help expand his business, Erisa has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy posho, rice, beans, salt, sodas, bananas, bread, and cooking oil and will help Erisa to generate greater profits and increase his stock. Erisa hopes that in the future, he will be able to expand to more outlets. 

Erisa is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Erisa who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy posho, rice, beans, salt, sodas, bananas, bread, and cooking oil

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 29 years. She is married to Daniel and together they have been blessed with two children who are two and four years old .Daniel operates a transport business to provide additional income for his family.

Beatrice sells groceries, a business she has done for the last six years, earning a monthly income of KES 40,000 including profit from the transport business, which she also does. 

Beatrice has requested her second loan with VisionFund Kenya of KES 70,000, which she will use to buy building materials for rental houses. Such materials include cement, sand, ballast and iron sheets. This is a business venture she has been longing to establish and she knows it will prosper and add extra income apart from her grocery sales

With the anticipated profits, Beatrice will be able to pay school fees for her children. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to have a stable source of income and business, which will ensure her children are educated for life.

loans.use: to buy building materials for rental houses

loans.name: Ralito

texts.en:
Ralito is a fisherman who is married and has three children. The oldest is 21, while the youngest is 8 years old. He sells fish to the nearby towns as his main source of income. He has been fishing for almost 20 years. He has also a fish pond, which is a big help to his family, especially during times that scarcity of catch occurs.  

Ralito lives with his family in Palompon, Leyte. Ralito is requesting a loan in the amount of 18,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) in order to buy fishing net, fish feed and materials, and to pay for labor to repair the pump boat. These are important tools to continue his livelihood, and definitely will improve his catch.

 Ralito hopes that he will utilize and manage well his fishing business for the welfare of his growing children.

loans.use: to buy fishing net, fish feed and materials, and pay for labor to repair the pump boat

loans.name: Jose Angel

texts.es:
José Ángel tiene 62 años de edad, vive en casa propia de material rustico junto a su esposa y sus 02 hijos. El domicilio del cliente se ubica en el caserío Sillagante aproximadamente a 2 hora del distrito de Pucará, en la provincia de Cutervo, región de Cajamarca. La comunidad donde vive el cliente es una pequeña zona rural donde los habitantes se conocen y dan buenas referencias personales y laborales. Su comunidad está dedicada básicamente a la agricultura, ganadería y al comercio.

La actividad que realiza José Ángel es la de sembrar café variedad Catimor. El préstamo lo utilizará para invertir en mantenimiento del terreno cultivable. Esta inversión le permitirá ganancias para mejorar su condición económica y por ende invertir en mejores condiciones de vida y la de toda su familia.
texts.en:
José Ángel, age 62, lives in his own house, which is made of basic materials.  He lives with his wife and their two children.  The house is in the Sillagante settlement, which is approximately two hours from the Pucará district, Cutervo province, Cajamarca region.  The community where he lives is a small rural area where the inhabitants know each other and give good personal and work references.  His community devotes itself basically to agriculture, livestock, and commerce.

José Ángel’s business activity is growing the Catimor variety of coffee.  He will use the loan for maintenance of the arable land.  This investment will allow him to get earnings to improve his financial condition.  As a result he will invest in better living condition for all of his family.

loans.use: to provide maintenance on the arable land.

loans.name: Kai

texts.en:
Kai is married and has been blessed with two school children who go to school. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past eight years, he has operated a dairy farming business, selling as retail and at the market to local residents and restaurant operators. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his place of operation. He dreams of adding more dairy cows and expand to a motorcycle business. 

With the Kshs 50,000 he wants to purchase medicine for livestock and cow feeds. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase medicine for livestock, and cow feeds.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is a single man; he lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food for his family.

Michael has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to neighbours and passersby. He faces stiff competition from other charcoal operators in his business.
 
With the Kshs 40,000 he wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy additional livestock in order to increase his profits and to pay for his children's education.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase three pigs and 12 bags of cement for pigpen construction to start commercial pig production.

loans.name: Mazahir

texts.en:
Mazahir is married and has four children. He lives in the Baku region, but for over 22 years he was an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from Xocali City. He has a small store, where he sells women accessories. 

Mazahir requested a loan from Komak Credit Union for 1,350 AZN, which he will use to buy goods (earrings, necklaces, rings, bags, purse, scarves and etc.) to support the development of business. In the future, He wants to repair the area of his store.

loans.use: to buy goods

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 42 years old and lives in the town of Ojwina in the Lira region of Uganda. He is married, and has six children, with two of them currently in school. For the past four years, Charles has been working hard to manage his drug shop, which sells drugs. 

To help expand his business, Charles has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drugs, and will help Charles to generate greater profits and increase the inventory. Charles hopes that in the future he will be able to establish another business. 

Charles is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Charles who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more drugs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy iron, cement blocks, cement, sand, and gravel.

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en:
Haruna is 37 years old and lives in the town of Luwero in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children with 3 of them currently in school. For the past 7 years, Haruna has been working hard to manage his poultry business, rearing poultry birds. 

To help expand his business, Haruna has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chicks, and will help Haruna to generate greater profits. Haruna hopes that in the future he will be able to have a large poultry farm. 

Haruna is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Haruna who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more chicks

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 53 years old and lives in the town of Lira in the Lira region of Uganda. She is married, and has five children, with two of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, she has been working hard to manage her retail baby shop, which sells baby items. 

To help expand her business, Margaret has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase baby clothes, and will help Margaret to generate greater profits and increase sales. Margaret hopes that in the future she will be able to educate her children. 

Margaret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Margaret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase baby clothes

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali  is a married mother of four children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the several past years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of Kes 50,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes to sell

loans.name: Merlyne

texts.en:
Merlyne is from the town of Baybay in Leyte. She is 34 years old, married with four children, ages 1-14. She farms root crops like taro, sweet potatoes, cassava and bananas. She also sell beauty products and clothes, usually called RTW (ready-to-wear) clothing. Usually, clothing under this name is cheaper compared to some designer clothes. Her livelihood started 12 years ago. Merlyne is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and more clothes to sell. 

She hopes to continue improving in her business so she can expand and increase business profitability to support her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her crops and clothes to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a married woman. She has 2 children. She describes herself as innovative. She operates a tailoring shop where she makes clothes. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a favorable location and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate capital. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of tailoring materials. Her business goal is to open more shops within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will improve her living standards. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tailoring materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a new boat engine for fishing and additional stock to sell, such as canned goods, noodles, sodas, beverages, soap and toiletries

loans.name: Rebiyanto

texts.en:
This is the story of Kamsyatri, daughter of Rebiyanto :

My name is Kamsyatri Deasytuti. I’m the second of three in my family. My father's name is Rebiyanto. My mother is named Misriyah. My father is a merchant. 

Everyday my father goes around to the villages to offer his wares by bicycle. But when the merchandise is not sold my father works as a bricklayer. Usually he earns Rp 700,000 per month from his job. 

My thanks to God because I‘m a very good student;  I am first in my class.

loans.use: to pay for education fees at the vocational school

loans.name: Kinepna Group

texts.en:
Themkhoneng is a mother of two sons and one daughter from a village far from town. She is the featured borrower of the group, pictured with her hand raised. She sells vegetables in the nearest market from her village and supports her family from the small profit she makes. She loves her children unconditionally and has worked very hard to support them. 

Themkhoneng wishes she could provide her children with all their material needs so that they do not envy their friends in their social environment. “To meet their material needs is not easy. I can barely buy them new clothes to replace the worn-out ones” she said. She is very protective and gives all her attention to her children. Like every other mother, she wishes her children to become successful and have decent careers in the future. 

Her husband is engaged in shifting cultivation and he grows peas, beans, potatoes, corn. She aspires to have a piggery at home to rear piglets so that she can sell the full-grown pigs as a source of income generation. Rearing piglets is considered very beneficial in the area because most of the tribes buy pigs for consumption whenever they have social and cultural occasions, celebrations and ceremonies. 

With the Kiva loan, Themkhoneng will buy piglets and also build a low cost piggery inside their house compound.  She is skilled in rearing pigs and has got experience since they had a piggery in their childhood home where she grew up. She is excited and sends her good wishes to the lenders. 

The other group members are engaged in piggery, pea plantation, tea stall, dairy farming and cabbage farming. They are all working very hard to achieve their financial goals.

loans.use: To buy piglets for rearing and to sell.

loans.name: Supriyanti

texts.en:
This is the story of Crisna, daughter of Supriyanti:

My mother works in Jakarta as a babysitter. Her income per month is approximately Rp.1,300,000. Each month she always sent my school fees and those of my brother; the rest was for pocket money and we would eat less. My father worked as a driver at one of the companies. He earns about 2,000,000 per month. But my father did not pay for my school and that of my younger siblings, never even supports me every month. Because there is a fairly heavy conflict within the family, my mother worked to earn money for my living expenses with income less pretty.

loans.use: to pay for education fees at the vocational school

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 32 years old and lives in the town of Ojwina in the Lira region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, with one of them currently in school. For the past two years, Emmanuel has been working hard to manage his restaurant.

To help expand his business, Emmanuel has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food items, and will help Emmanuel to generate greater profits and stock food in bulk. Emmanuel hopes that in the future, he will be able to own a good-looking restaurant. 

Emmanuel is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Emmanuel who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy food items.

loans.name: Mavzuna

texts.en:
Mavzuna was born in 1980. She is divorced and has four children. She is the only provider for her children.

Mavzuna has been busy with her sewing business for more than three years. She sews national womens' dresses. Mavzuna little by little develops her business and attracts more clients. Now, she is going to buy a new sewing machine for increasing her working capital and in this way improve her business.

She is asking for a loan of 5,000 Tajikistan Somoni (TJS). This loan will help her to develop her business and to get success. She awaits your help.

loans.use: to buy new sewing machine for increasing working capital.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, pest control, etc and to improve his land

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is a married woman from Carles, Ilo-ilo. She is 59 year old, who engages in fishing.She catches and sells fish to the people in the community.She has five children. Her youngest child is 14 year old.  Due to financial problem, Edna  has requested a loan of 30,000 PHP to buy fishing materials like fishing net and materials for construction of pump boat. These will help improve her daily yield  and hopefully provide her family with nutritious food and also continue send her children to school.

In the future, Edna would like to expand her fishing business for sustainable livelihood.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like fishing net and materials for construction of pumpboat

loans.name: Zaynura

texts.en:
Zaynura was born in 1978. She is married and has four children. She lives with her family in a rural area. She always cares for the well-being of her children, so she started her own business dealing with animal husbandry five months ago. She has one cow and two sheep. She feeds cattle at her house where she has a cowshed. 

Zaynura is going to increase the number of cattle she feeds and in this way will develop her new business. With this aim, Zaynura took part in a course called "To Get Ahead" sponsored by a women's organization and got a certificate. She learnt a lot of new information. She is asking for a loan of 600 TJS to buy sheep to increase the working capital of her new business. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: To buy sheep to increase working capital of her new business

loans.name: Kanifa

texts.en:
For some months Kanifa has been busy with an animal husbandry business. She always dreamed to run own a business deal, and in this way to get ahead in life. 

Kanifa is married and brings up two children. Kanifa and her family live in the country, which is located in the north part of Tajikistan. Kanifa bought a sheep, and now she is going to increase the number of sheep she feeds. Kanifa took part in a course, ‘To Get Ahead’, with a woman's organization and got a certificate. She learned a lot of useful information for herself and to develop the business further. Kanifa’s husband helps her to feed sheep. 

She is asking for a loan of 600 somoni to buy sheep. She awaits your mercy and, in advance, thanks Kiva lenders for their generosity.

loans.use: To buy sheep for organizing a new business

loans.name: Hùng

texts.en:
Hùng, 41, is married with two children. He lives with two dependents in Thanh Hoa City, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province. Hùng has a service business laying bricks and has been in this business for more than 10 years. 

In 2013, Hùng joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Hùng has successfully repaid one loan from this organization.

The main hardship that Hùng faces in her life is not having a hygeinic latrine. He is requesting a loan to purchase sand, cement and brick to build a toilet.

With his business profit, Hùng hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for his business to do well and for his children to do well in school.

loans.use: to purchase sand, cement and brick to build a  toilet.

loans.name: Nhóm 06_Thôn 4_Đông Minh Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lan has a tailoring service. Lan has been involved in this business for five years. She is requesting a loan to purchase more cloth to repair clothes and sew clothes for sale. 

Lan is 30 years old, and she is married with two children. She is the group leader of the Nhóm 06_Thôn 4_Đông Minh  solidarity group, which consists of four members. 

This is Lan’s first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. The main hardship that Lan faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Lan hopes for her business to do well, to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business, and to make enough money to provide for her kids.

loans.use: to purchase more cloth to repair clothes and sew clothes for sale

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is driven by passion in selling. At the age of 38, a married woman in Sindangan, ZND, she runs a store that primarily supports her family. She never gets tired of tending her store. 

Rosalie is a full-fledged member of PMPC and has taken several loans already. She religiously paid her obligations without records of default. 

Now, she borrowed another loan to pay for inventories of sugar, milk, oil, and noodles to sell. Having enough inventory means income opportunities. Rosalie is eyeing on a car wash business. She wishes to buy initial equipment and gadgets like water hose and water tank. She hopes that her income will be doubled and save enough for children's education.

In the future, she dreams of sustaining her store to continuously provide for her family.

loans.use: To buy groceries, and add as capital for car wash to sustain income generation.

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.en:
Erneto is thankful that he was granted a 15,000 PHP loan, which he used to purchase various grocery items and products needed in his General Store. Through his earnings, he is able to send his children to school and meet their daily living expense. 

He would now like to apply for a 15,000 PHP loan, which he will use to buy more quantities of grocery items like rice, coffee, soda, and rice noodles. He also sells fish, which he sells at retail. He is positive that more items will yield more sales and thus increase his earnings. His business earnings are a stable source to sustain his family's basic needs and for the education of his children. He is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given him. 

Ernesto dreams of having a bigger General Store and aims to give his children the best education possible for them to have a better future. Every week, he meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which he studies .

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in his business.

loans.name: Agapita

texts.en:
Agapita, 66 years old, is married with three adult children. She is a resident of D'ban, Calamba, Philippines. 

She has been in this business for more than a decade. Flower vending is her primary source of livelihood. She became a member of Paglaum MPC in June 2000. Recently, Agapita decided to apply for a loan to purchase bulk inventories of flowers for resale because Christmas is coming and demand for flowers is high. She hopes to increase her income with more inventory to sell and pay for two months only. In the future, she hopes to save more for the education of her grandchildren.

loans.use: to purchase bulk inventories of flowers for resale

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita makes a good earning in every quarter from her cocoland in Dolore, Tudela. This is how she supports her family and she was able to send all her children to school until they graduated and got their own jobs. Out of the money she saved, she bought two hectares of land. Now, she wants to plant more good varieties of dwarf coconuts to increase her farm yield. She is in need of working capital, she presented her project to Paglaum and requested a loan of PHP 50,000 to pay for labor costs for land clearing, plowing and seedling mounting. She has high hopes that she will have good produce in three years time.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs for land clearing, plowing and seedling mounting

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
This is Josie, 43, a resident of Dasmarinas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Hesus, a Captain Mariner, and has two children. The elder is in high school and the younger is in elementary level. 
 
Josie has been renting out her other house to a Christian school for ten years already. She also sells direct-selling personal products such as beauty products, undergarments, and Royal whitening soaps where she is shown on her photo. She earns a minimum of PHP 400 from her direct-selling business. Her earnings help sustain their daily needs and in sending her kids to school.

She is now requesting a PHP 10,000 loan for the proper maintenance and safety of the schoolhouse. She is glad that her house is being leased by the Christian school, which has an increased number of children being enrolled. She is positive that her tenant is happy and satisfied with her maintenance of the schoolhouse, and is assured of a continued lease on her property.   

Josie dreams to expand her property and be successful in her direct-selling business.  She aims to give her kids the best education and ensure them a bright future. She prays that they will always lead a godly life. 

Josie meets with her co-fellowship members* every week, to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for repair and maintenance of her rental house.

loans.name: Edmund

texts.en:
His name is Edmund, 41,and he is a resident of Dasmarinas, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Elaine, a businesswoman, and has three children who are all in the Elementary Level. His wife is a direct seller of Vita-Plus and they both work to meet their everyday needs and to support their  children's schooling. 

Edmund has been operating a tricycle for three years already. His tricycle carries up to four passengers. In the Philippines, especially in the province of Dasmarinas, a tricycle is a common means of transportation. Jeepneys and buses are limited . Very few people own a vehicle.  The town people usually ride a tricycle from their homes to the market, church, to their friends' homes and to other destinations within their community. They even  transport from one town to the other. He earns a minimum of PHP 500 a day.

To help him continue his transport business, he is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan, which he will use to pay for gas and maintenance of his tricycle. He is positive that this will boost his income as tricycle transportation is really a necessity in their area.

Edmund dreams of being successful in his business so he can give his family a much better life. He aims to give his children the best education. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for maintenance and gas for his tricycle service.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a hardworking entrepreneur who buys and sells charcoal in the Philippines. Gloria earns more income from a general store and also from pig fattening.

She is borrowing 30,000 PHP through NWTF to buy sacks of charcoal to sell for her charcoal business. She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her business. Gloria has been in this business for 11 years. Gloria has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Madonna

texts.en:
Madonna is a married woman with three children. She is 31 years old and has two children who are currently in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur with a general store business in the Philippines. 

Madonna requested a 12000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more items like canned goods, soft-drinks, coffee, sugar, noodles, etc. to sell in her general store.

Madonna has been in this business for 3 years. In the future, Madonna would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more items like canned goods, soft-drinks, coffee, sugar, noodles, etc. to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of household goods to sell like can goods, egg, noodles, etc in her general store business.
 
Gloria has been in this business for 4 years. Gloria earns additional income from raising pigs.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Gloria has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of household goods to sell like can goods, egg, noodles, etc

loans.name: Rahima

texts.en:
Rahima is a 49-year-old lady living in Dair Alla, Jordan with her family that consists of six members. 

She has been helping her husband in improving their living conditions and covering their children's needs by selling blankets at her house to her neighbors and friends for two years. Because she built a good customer base, she decided to purchase clothes to sell. But because she doesn't have enough money to do so, she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Saadatbu

texts.ru: Саадатбу, 48 лет, вдова, есть 4 детей, младшему 16 лет. С 1991 года занимается животноводством, начав этот бизнес с 10,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорству и целеустремленности Саадатбу, она достигла хороших результатов и на сегодняшний день в ее хозяйстве имеется: 2 коровы, 1 бычок, 5 овец, 5 коз, 1 лошадь. Дети помогают по хозяйству. Семья очень трудолюбивая и дружная. Ежемесячная прибыль составляет 8,000 сом (KGS). Этих средств катастрофически не хватает на достойную жизнь и воспитание детей, Саадатбу видит источник дохода в своем хозяйстве, поэтому она в целях увеличения поголовья скота обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом, в сумме 70,000 сом (KGS) на покупку 2 коров. На доходы от кредита Саадатбу планирует и дальше развивать свое хозяйство, что позволит ей в будущем увеличить доходы семьи и улучшить благосостояние.
texts.en: Saadatbu is 48 years old, a widow, and the mother of four children.  Her youngest child is 16 years old.  She has been involved in animal husbandry since 1991 when she started in this business using an initial capital of 10,000 som (KGS).  Thanks to her perseverance and determination, she has achieved good results, and she now owns one cow, one young bull, five sheep, five goats and one horse.  Her children help her run the farming business.  Saadbatbu's family is very hardworking and friendly.  Saadatbu makes a monthly income of 8,000 som (KGS), which is vastly insufficient to provide a decent living and to cover the children's needs.  Realizing that she could make more money with her farming business and in order to increase her cattle headcount, she has turned to Bai Tushum Bank CJSC and requested a loan of 70,000 som (KGS).  She will use this loan to buy two cows.  She plans to use the earnings from her loan into further developing her business, so that she can increase her family's income in the future and improve their welfare.

loans.use: to purchase two cows in order to increase her livestock headcount and her income.

loans.name: Camilo Andres

texts.es:
Camilo es un joven con todas las pilas puestas para enfrentar el mundo y tener una vida plena gracias a sus esfuerzos.

Tiene un almacén en el que vende accesorios de vestir como bolsos. Inicio el negocio hace 15 años y  ha tenido buena acogida en el sector.

El desea ampliar su oferta de productos y mejorar aun mas sus ventas inyectándole capital a su empresa, es por esta razón que solicita un crédito para darse la oportunidad surtir su negocio con mas variedad de bolsos para dama.

Tiene grandes esperanzas en su negocio y piensa que su futuro puede mejorar considerablemente gracias al apoyo de estas entidades que hacen lo posible para que las personas puedan soñar con una vida mejor y más estable.
texts.en:
Camilo is a young man who is well prepared to make his way in the world and achieve a full life through hard work. He has for the past 15 years owned a shop where he sells accessories such as handbags, and has achieved success. 

Camilo wants to offer his customers a greater variety of merchandise and boost his sales further by investing capital. He is therefore applying for a loan so that he can stock his shop with a greater variety of women's handbags. 

Camilo has great ambitions for his business and thinks he will enjoy a much brighter future thanks to lending institutions that allow people to dream of a better and more stable life.

loans.use: to stock his shop with a greater variety of women's handbags.

loans.name: Samah

texts.en: Because Samah is a conservative lady, she asked her brother in Law to take her place in the picture. Samah is a 23-year-old married lady living with her husband in Irbid, Jordan. Her husband is taking care of his brothers. One of his brothers is a university student majoring in History, and he is in his second year. Samah's husband is currently facing financial crisis, which means he is not able to pay his brother's school fees. For that, Samah wants to help him by applying for this loan.

loans.use: To pay for upcoming semester fees

loans.name: Jummai

texts.en:
Jummai is a maize farmer from Nigeria. She is the mother of 3 children.

A loan from Kiva helps Jummai to purchase fertilizer for her crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable her to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, she had to sell her maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, she can now store her maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows her to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

When asked, Jummai spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to make more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural inputs and store her harvest to sell it later for higher profits

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: Nasreen is a 39-year-old married woman. She is a mother of three children. Her son owns a clothing sales business, which is the only source of income for the family. Presently she needs additional capital for the growth of her son's clothing sale business. For that, Nasreen is requesting a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan for her son to purchase a variety of clothes to sell to enable him to respond quickly to customer needs. With the help of profits, he will save an amount to pay the electricity and gas bill. Nasreen hopes that the loan will be helpful for her son's business. She is thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to enhance her son's clothing sales business.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is a maize farmer from Nigeria. She is the mother of 3 children.

A loan from Kiva helps Noami to purchase fertilizer for higher crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable her to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, she had to sell her maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, she can now store her maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows her to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

Naomi spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and store her harvest to sell it later in the year at higher prices

loans.name: Ron's Group

texts.en: Ron’s group live in a rural village in Kompong Thom province in Cambodia. Ron makes a living cultivating rice to support his family. In her village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these woman and man to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for her family.

loans.name: Salisu

texts.en:
Salisu is a maize farmer from Nigeria. He is the father of 3 children.

A loan from Kiva helps Salisu to purchase fertilizer for his crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable him to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, he had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher.

This allows him to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

Salisu will use the additional income to educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and store his harvest to sell it later at higher prices

loans.name: Amal

texts.en:
Amal, a 35 year old Palestinian woman, is an exceptional ambitious woman  who has a cosmetics shop that sells make up cremes, accessories and perfumes. She is married with two children, both in elementary school. Her husband works in a dairy factory. Amal has been running her business for three years now, she is showing great and impressive business and managerial skills.
Amal is asking for a 2,827,983 Lebanese pounds loan for the first time from Kiva partner Ibdaa. She is planning on using the loan to increase her stocks in beauty products and enhance her salon's decor.

loans.use: to buy beauty products and improve her salon's decor

loans.name: Delmy De Jesus

texts.es: Delmy de 60 años de edad desde hace varios años se dedica a la crianza de cerdos, comercializa los cerdos en los diferentes mercados, con las ventas que realiza logra salir adelante con los gastos del hogar, Delmy vive en casa propia con su hija, ella esta solicitando un crédito para poder comprar concentrado para los cerdos y asi poder continuar con la crianza de los mismo y tener mejores ganancias.
texts.en: Delmy is 60 years old and has made a living raising pigs for a number of years.  She sells pigs in different markets and with the money she makes from sales she can stay on top of household expenses. Delmy lives in her own home with her daughter. She is requesting a loan to buy concentrated feed for her pigs and in this way be able to continue raising them and improve her income.

loans.use: to buy concentrated pig feed

loans.name: Maria Violeta

texts.es:
Maria Violeta tiene 36 años de edad, es madre soltera, vive en casa propia de material rustico, vive con su hijo de 4 años de edad. Maria Violeta vive en la parte rural de su distrito contando con servicios de agua y luz. Su comunidad está dedicada básicamente a la agricultura, ganadería y al comercio. Y está ubicada en el distrito de Pucará, provincia de Jaén, región de Cajamarca, sierra norte de Perú.

La actividad que realiza Maria Violeta es la venta de combustible: como gasolina, petroleo así como también vende cerveza y comida, las ventas lo realiza en su domicilio. El destino del crédito será para invertir en compra de mayor cantidad de combustible, con ello le generará mayores ingresos y así poder mejorar su calidad de vida. Para este rubro no hay mayor competencia en la zona y con ello obtiene mejores precios.
texts.en:
Maria Violeta is 36 years old. She is a single mother who lives in her own house made of basic materials with her 4-year-old son. Most people in her community work in agriculture, livestock-farming and business. It is located in the district of Pucará, Jaén Province, which is part of the region of Cajamarca in the northern mountains of Peru.  

Maria Violeta sells fuel, such as gasoline and petroleum. She also sells beer and food, all from her home. The loan will be used to buy a greater quantity of fuel, with which she will generate greater income and will be able to improve her quality of life. In this branch of sales there is not much competition in the area so Maria Violeta gets better prices.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity of fuel

loans.name: La'azarus

texts.en:
La'azarus is a maize farmer from Nigeria. He is the father of 2 children.

A loan from Kiva helps La'azarus to purchase fertilizer for his crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable him to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, he had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows him to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

“I would like to use this additional income to educate my children," La'azarus said. "And ultimately, I hope to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs."

loans.use: To buy agricultural inputs and store his harvest to sell it later on at higher prices

loans.name: Nura

texts.en:
Nura is a maize farmer from Nigeria. He is the father of one child.

A loan from Kiva helps Nura to purchase fertilizer for his crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable him to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, he had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows him to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

“I would like to use this additional income to educate my child," Nura said "And ultimately, I hope to make more money for myself and my family."

loans.use: To buy agricultural input and store his harvest to sell it later on at higher prices

loans.name: Barnabus

texts.en:
Barnabus is a maize farmer from Nigeria. He is the father of 3 children.

A loan from Kiva helps Barnabus to purchase fertilizer for his crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable him to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, he had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows him to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

Barnabus would like to use this additional income to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy agricultural inputs and store his harvest to sell it later at higher prices

loans.name: Yunusa

texts.en:
Yunusa is a maize farmer from Nigeria. He is the father of 3 children.

A loan from Kiva helps Yunusa to purchase fertilizer for his crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable him to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, he had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows Yunusa to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

loans.use: To buy agricultural inputs and store his harvest to sell it later for more profit

loans.name: Jose Salomon

texts.es: Jose de 55 años de edad vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, el se dedica a la pesca artesanal desde hace 10 años experiencia que le ha dado la oportunidad de vender una buena calidad de producto por esa razón posee clientes fijos, Don Jose esta solicitando nuevamente un crédito para comprar trasmallos, redes y darle mantenimiento a la lancha ya que le ha ido muy bien con las ventas y esa es su única fuente de trabajo y de ingresos.
texts.en: Jose is 55 years of age and lives in his own home with his family. He has made a living from artisanal fishing for 10 years. This experience has given him the opportunity to sell a good quality product and for that reason he has regular customers.  Don Jose is requesting a loan once again to buy trammel nets and to carry out maintenance on his boat, because his sales, which are his only source of work and income, have been very good.

loans.use: to purchase trammel nets and to carry out maintenance on his boat

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy corn, cracklings, beans, cheese, etc.

loans.name: Kanenga Group

texts.fr:
Monami  fait partie du groupe Kanenga  et  habite à Bubanza, Burundi. Il a 35 ans et est marie  une cultivatrice. Ensemble ils ont 3 enfants âgés de 1 à 12 ans, dont 2 étudient.

Il fait le commerce de boutique (riz, haricot, farine de manioc,…) depuis 12 ans.

Il  est à son deuxième  crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il obtient, il  va  augmenter son capital et acheter une  grande quantité de riz et de haricot à revendre pour gagner plus

Dans  prochaines années, il voudrait acheter une moto pour vendre le service de transport par moto et voir ses enfants étudier.
texts.en:
Monami  is part of the group called Kanenga and lives in Bubanza, Burundi. He is 35 years old and is married to a farmer. Together they have three children aged between 1 and 12 years, of whom 2 are enrolled in school. 

Monami has been selling foodstuffs (rice, beans, manioc flour, etc.) for 12 years. 

He is on his second loan from Turame. With the Kiva loan he hopes to receive, he is going to grow his capital and buy a big quantity of rice and beans for resale so as to earn more income. 

In the next few years, he would like to buy a motorcycle so as to get paid for doing motorcycle transport and see his children attend school.

loans.use: to grow his capital and buy a lot of rice and beans for resale so as to make more income

loans.name: Laazarus

texts.en:
Lazarus is a maize farmer from Nigeria. He is the father of 3 children.

A loan from Kiva helps Lazarus to purchase fertilizer for his crops and also to obtain a training course in agronomy and business. This will enable him to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize - double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. 

Also, before joining Babban Gona, he had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest in order to pay for urgent expenses, such as food and school fees. With the Kiva loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest and sell it later at prices up to 40% higher. 

This allows him to generate earnings of up to $1,000/hectare, more than four times Nigerian farmers' annual income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and store his harvest to sell it later at higher prices

“I would like to use this additional income to educate my children", La'azarus said. "Ultimately I hope to become the most profitable farmer in my community."

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and store his harvest to sell it later for bigger profits
